Simple GUI

[code]import javax.swing.*;[/code] This is used to import everything from javax.swing. The asterisk is used to show that everything in swing is needed and therefore imported. 
public class SimpleFrame extends JFrame {

Public class is simple. Doesn’t need explaining but you must make it inherit JFrame, other wise it wont work. Inheritance is simple. “extends” creates SimpleFrame a subclass of JFrame. That makes JFrame a super class. A subclass can only have 1 superclass.

public SimpleFrame() {

Again, simple stuff. Not needed to explain

super("Frame Title");

You can probably guess. super() gives the frame a title. You can change it to whatever you want.

setSize(300, 100);

This sets the size of the frame. It is in !pixels!
Remember that capitalization is so important in Java, and if you forget to capitalize one letter, it will fail to compile.

setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

This sets it so whenever the user presses “X” you state what will happen. Below are your options:
EXIT_ON_CLOSE - Once the app is closed, everything stops.
DISPOSE_ON_CLOSE - Closes the frame, removes the frame from memory but will keep running the app.
DO_NOTHING_ON_CLOSE - Keeps the frame open and keeps running
HIDE_ON_CLOSE - Closes the frame but keeps running

setVisible(true); }
Makes the frame visible. Only boolean values (true or false) can go in the brackets.

public static void main(String[] arguments) {

Doesn’t need explaining

SimpleFrame sf = new SimpleFrame(); } }
Creates the frame that we created earlier.

The whole code:

[code]import javax.swing.*;

public class SimpleFrame extends JFrame {
public SimpleFrame() {
super(“Frame Title”);
setSize(300, 100);
setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
setVisible(true);
}
public static void main(String[] arguments) {
SimpleFrame sf = new SimpleFrame();
}
}[/code]

I hope you learnt something

I’ll be making more tutorials, and some of them will be on developing on GUIs

Creating Buttons On GUIs

[code]import javax.swing.*;[/code] This is used to import everything from javax.swing. The asterisk is used to show that everything in swing is needed and therefore imported. 
public class ButtonFrame extends JFrame {

Public class is simple. Doesn’t need explaining but you must make it inherit JFrame, other wise it wont work. Inheritance is simple. “extends” creates SimpleFrame a subclass of JFrame. That makes JFrame a super class. A subclass can only have 1 superclass.

JButton load = new JButton("Load"); JButton save = new JButton("Save"); JButton unsubscribe = new JButton("Unsubscribe");
JButton is the button and must be used for creating a simple button! You can name them whatever, but it is a lot easier to name them your button. Use small case to prevent confusion. new JButton() creates a new button with the text in. Put the text you want inside the brackets inside the "s.

public ButtonFrame() {

Doesn’t need explaining…I hope.

super("Button Frame");

You can probably guess. super() gives the frame a title. You can change it to whatever you want.

setSize(80, 170);

This sets the size of the frame. It is in !pixels!
Remember that capitalization is so important in Java, and if you forget to capitalize one letter, it will fail to compile.

setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

This sets it so whenever the user presses “X” you state what will happen. Below are your options:
EXIT_ON_CLOSE - Once the app is closed, everything stops.
DISPOSE_ON_CLOSE - Closes the frame, removes the frame from memory but will keep running the app.
DO_NOTHING_ON_CLOSE - Keeps the frame open and keeps running
HIDE_ON_CLOSE - Closes the frame but keeps running

JPanel pane = new JPanel();

Creates a new JPanel.

pane.add(load); pane.add(save); pane.add(unsubscribe);
Adds the buttons to the panel.

add(pane);

Adds the panel to the frame.

setVisible(true); }
Makes the frame visible. Only boolean values (true or false) can go in the brackets.

public static void main(String[] arguments) {

Shouldn’t need explaining

ButtonFrame bf = new ButtonFrame(); } }
Creates the frame that we created earlier.

The whole code:

[code]import javax.swing.*;

class ButtonFrame extends JFrame {
JButton load = new JButton(“Load”);
JButton save = new JButton(“Save”);
JButton unsubscribe = new JButton(“Unsubscribe”);

public ButtonFrame() {
	super("Button Frame");
	setSize(80, 170);
	setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
	JPanel pane = new JPanel();
	pane.add(load);
	pane.add(save);
	pane.add(unsubscribe);
	add(pane);
	setVisible(true);
}

public static void main(String[] arguments) {
	ButtonFrame bf = new ButtonFrame();
}

}[/code]

Learnt to add buttons! Well done

Creating Text Areas on A GUI

Learn!!!! 
import javax.swing.*;

This is used to import everything from javax.swing. The asterisk is used to show that everything in swing is needed and therefore imported.

public class Authenticator extends javax.swing.JFrame {

Public class is simple. Doesn’t need explaining but you must make it inherit JFrame, other wise it wont work. Inheritance is simple. “extends” creates SimpleFrame a subclass of JFrame. That makes JFrame a super class. A subclass can only have 1 superclass. You could just use “extends JFrame”.

JTextField username = new JTextField(15);

This creates a textfield. The “(15)” means that there is a 15 character cap.

JPasswordField password = new JPasswordField(15);

This creates a password field. The difference between a password field and a text field, is that the input in a password field is hidden. There is a 5 character cap.

JTextArea comments = new JTextArea(4, 15);

Creates a text area for comments. Allows 15 rows and 4 columns.

JButton ok = new JButton("Ok"); JButton cancel = new JButton("Cancel");
Creates 2 buttons called “Ok” and “Cancel”. You learnt about these Here

public Authenticator() {

No need to explain

super("Account Information"); setSize(300, 220); setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
You have learnt about these in the basics of creating a GUI.

JPanel pane = new JPanel();

Creates a new JPanel

JLabel usernameLabel = new JLabel("Username: "); JLabel passwordLabel = new JLabel("Password: "); JLabel commentsLabel = new JLabel("Comments: ");
Creates a label with the text in the brackets. Use these as information helping the user.

comments.setLineWrap(true);

This stops the text is the comment area from carrying on without making a new line. Using (false) stops this.

comments.setWrapStyleWord(true);

If a new line is needed in the comments area, the whole word will be moved to the next line. If you want it to make the letter go to the next line, use:

comments.setWrapStyleLetter(true);

pane.add(usernameLabel); pane.add(username); pane.add(passwordLabel); pane.add(password); pane.add(commentsLabel); pane.add(comments); pane.add(ok); pane.add(cancel);
Adds all of the fields to the panel.

add(pane); setVisible(true); }
Adds the pane and makes it visible.

public static void main(String[] arguments) { Authenticator auth = new Authenticator(); } }
Creates the frame that we created earlier.

Whole code:

[code]import javax.swing.*;

public class Authenticator extends javax.swing.JFrame {
JTextField username = new JTextField(15);
JPasswordField password = new JPasswordField(15);
JTextArea comments = new JTextArea(4, 15);
JButton ok = new JButton(“Ok”);
JButton cancel = new JButton(“Cancel”);

public Authenticator() {
	super("Account Information");
	setSize(300, 220);
	setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

	JPanel pane = new JPanel();
	JLabel usernameLabel = new JLabel("Username: ");
	JLabel passwordLabel = new JLabel("Password: ");
	JLabel commentsLabel = new JLabel("Comments: ");
	comments.setLineWrap(true);
	comments.setWrapStyleWord(true);
	pane.add(usernameLabel);
	pane.add(username);
	pane.add(passwordLabel);
	pane.add(password);
	pane.add(commentsLabel);
	pane.add(comments);
	pane.add(ok);
	pane.add(cancel);
	add(pane);
	setVisible(true);
}
public static void main(String[] arguments) {
	Authenticator auth = new Authenticator();
}

}
[/code]

Now you’ve learnt to make text areas

Creating A Slider

Time to learn how to make a slider :)

import java.awt.event.*; import javax.swing.*;
You know about this. Imports everything from javax.swing and awt.event.

public class Slider extends JFrame {

Simple…

public Slider() {

Again, simple.

super("Slider");

Sets the frame title. Change it to whatever.

setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

This sets it so whenever the user presses “X” you state what will happen. Below are your options:
EXIT_ON_CLOSE - Once the app is closed, everything stops.
DISPOSE_ON_CLOSE - Closes the frame, removes the frame from memory but will keep running the app.
DO_NOTHING_ON_CLOSE - Keeps the frame open and keeps running
HIDE_ON_CLOSE - Closes the frame but keeps running

JSlider pickNum = new JSlider(JSlider.HORIZONTAL, 0, 30, 5);

Gives the JSlider a name (pickNum) which creates a new slider, that is horizontal that goes from 0 - 30 with a number every 5 thingys 

pickNum.setMajorTickSpacing(10);

Sets a big line every 10 spaces.

pickNum.setMinorTickSpacing(1);

Sets a small line every 1 space.

pickNum.setPaintTicks(true);

Boolean value. True - shows the lines, false doesn’t,

pickNum.setPaintLabels(true);

Boolean value - True shows the numbers, false doesn’t.

add(pickNum); }
Adds all of above to pickNum.

public static void main(String[] args) {

Simple…Again… 

Slider frame = new Slider();

Creates the frame that we created earlier.

frame.pack();

Causes the frame to fit automatically without having to set the sizes.

frame.setVisible(true); } }
Makes the frame visible.

The whole code:

[code]import java.awt.event.;
import javax.swing.;

public class Slider extends JFrame {

public Slider() {
	super("Slider");
	setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
	JSlider pickNum = new JSlider(JSlider.HORIZONTAL, 0, 30, 5);
	pickNum.setMajorTickSpacing(10);
	pickNum.setMinorTickSpacing(1);
	pickNum.setPaintTicks(true);
	pickNum.setPaintLabels(true);
	add(pickNum);
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
	Slider frame = new Slider();
	frame.pack();
	frame.setVisible(true);
}

}
[/code]

Very simple stuff.

Pretty soon I’ll do a tutorial with like 50 lines of code, but it may take a long time to comment each line

Really Simple Dice Game

A simple dice game. Really made for learning purposes as there is not much you can do with this. 
class DiceGame {

Creates the class when compiled.

public static void main(String[] arguments) {

Simple, shouldn’t have to explain.

int die1; int die2; int roll; int score; int hiScore = 10; int snakeEyes = 2;
This states the variables. We are only using integers for this, which are WHOLE numbers. These are used mostly for numbers, but there are a few other variables you can use.
You can change the hi-score to whatever you want, but keep it below 11.
Don’t change the ‘snakeEyes’ value.

die1 = (int) (Math.random()*6) + 1; die2 = (int) (Math.random()*6) + 1;
This ‘rolls’ dice one and two, using the Math.random() method. This gets a random number from 1 - 6 (The numbers on a dice)

roll = die1 + die2;

This gives the ‘roll’ integer the value of dice 1 and dice 2 AFTER they have been ‘rolled’.

score = die1 + die2;

This gives the ‘score’ integer the value of the two dice AFTER they have been rolled.

System.out.println("The first die comes up: " + die1); System.out.println("The second die comes up: " + die2); System.out.println("Your total roll is: " + roll);
System.out.println() is a method that puts output to the debug box for the user to see. As you can see, you need to put the output in ""s. If you want to add a value of an integer, you need to close the "s and put ’ + INTEGER HERE’

Below, we will use three ‘if’ statements. These might be a bit advanced for very beginners.

if(score == snakeEyes) { System.out.println("!***Snake Eyes***!"); }
In this if statement, we are pretty much saying the following:
IF the score only equals the snakeEyes integer (2) then run the following block of code.
Then the System.out.println() method, shows the user that they rolled two 1s.

if(score == 12) { System.out.println("!***!Max Dice Roll!***!"); }
This if statement is saying:
IF your new score only equals 12 then run the following block of code.
System.out.println out puts that you have rolled a max dice roll, which is 12. That means you ‘rolled’ two 6s.

if(score > hiScore) { System.out.println("You beat the hi-score of: " + hiScore + "\nThe new hi-score is: " + score); score = hiScore; } } }
This if statement is saying:
IF your new score, after the roll, is greater than “>” the hiScore integer then run this block of code:
Output in the debug box "You beat the hi-score of: " and then add the original hiScore integer.
The “\n” prints out a blank line. It then outputs "The new hi-score is: " + the original score integer.

The whole code:

[code]class DiceGame {
public static void main(String[] arguments) {
int die1;
int die2;
int roll;
int score;
int hiScore = 10;
int snakeEyes = 2;

	die1 = (int) (Math.random()*6) + 1;
	die2 = (int) (Math.random()*6) + 1;
	roll = die1 + die2;
	score = die1 + die2;

	System.out.println("The first die comes up: " + die1);
	System.out.println("The second die comes up: " + die2);
	System.out.println("Your total roll is: " + roll);
	if(score == snakeEyes) {
				System.out.println("!***Snake Eyes***!");
	}
		if(score == 12) {
						System.out.println("!***!Max Dice Roll!***!");
	}
	System.out.println(" ");
	System.out.println("Your total score is: " + score);


	if(score > hiScore) {
				System.out.println("You beat the hi-score of: " + hiScore + "\nThe new hi-score is: " + score);
				score = hiScore;
			}
		}

}[/code]

I explained it badly in some places, but I hope you have learnt some things
